page.title: 16EASTHAM 60 YRS OF CHANGE (2)
page.content: NOW IN 1985, FARM PRODUCE IS MOVED ALMOST ENTIRELY BY ROAD ,WITH FRUIT BEING TAKEN BY LORRY TO EARLY MORNING MARKETS,AND ANIMALS BEING TRANSPORTED IN CATTLE TRUCKS. MOST HOUSEHOLDS HAVE AT LEAST ONE CAR. THERE IS JUST ONE BUS A MONTH TO KIDDERMINSTER, AND SCHOOL BUSES AND TUESDAY AND SATURDAY BUSES TO TENBURY.THERE IS NO SHOP,POST OFFICE, SCHOOL OR SMITHY, AND PEOPLE SHOP MAINLY IN TENBURY.VERY FEW PEOPLE KEEP POULTRY OR PIGS, THOUGH THERE ARE SOME BEE KEEPERS IN THE AREA.THERE ARE FAR FEWER HOPYARDS NOW AND ONLY A FEW FARMERS STILL MAKE CIDER.CORN IS HARVESTED WITH A COMBINE HARVESTER AND MUCH OF THE FORMER EXCITEMENT IS MISSING FROM HARVEST TIME AND HOP_PICKING.
